description: The object of the game is to be the first player to capture four Hoppin' Poppin" Spaceballs of the same color while flipping out any balls of another color. Players hit levers to knock out other-colored balls, while trying to retain balls of their color.

Thermopylae is a print and play solo mini wargame representing stand of Ancient Greek soldiers against Persian invasion.
In this game you will take the role of 300 Spartans who took their last stand at Thermopylae Pass to protect retreat of the main body of Greek army.
Game can be played by using given board and counters, but if the player wishes, it can be played with miniatures on the game board, or even with chess figures on chess table (this might be a good way to find a new use for your miniature magnetic chess set while on the road). 
Game is played this by rolling a set of dices looking for doubles. Each double equals one action (move, ranged or close combat) in fight against enemy units moved by game system. Once all the enemies on the board are eliminated, new ones enter from western table edge. Game ends when all player units are eliminated, or when the first enemy unit exits board trough the eastern table edge.

Game is free, and can be downloaded from here: http://battreps.blogspot.com/2011/06/thermopylae.html

Inspector Moss must investigate the mysterious death of millionaire baker, John Dough, who has been found battered at his stately country manor during a social gathering in the bachelor’s home. With an injunction in place to keep the guests from leaving, Moss has only a short window of opportunity to investigate and question the suspects. Can he eliminate the innocent and arrest the culprit before the injunction expires?

In this game, you get to play as Inspector Moss, exploring a 25-room house consisting of tiles. Each tile contains either a suspect, evidence that can be used to eliminate suspects, or something to assist you in solving the case in time.

On each turn, you roll 7 white dice and 1 colored "time" die up to 3 times. You may then use up to 6 of the dice for movement (by matching the number on the destination tile), for gathering evidence (with any 4 consecutive dice), and for getting assistance (with any 3 matching dice). After performing any actions, you must move the time marker down a number of spaces equal to the number shown on the time die plus 1 minute for every wild 6 that was used for an action.

There are 10 possible suspects in the game. Once you have collected enough evidence to eliminate 9 of them, you must arrest the remaining suspect and escort him/her to the waiting police car. If you can do all of this before time runs out, you win the game.

The Game At A Glance:  Appalachian Rails is based on the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad and its march across the coalfields of West Virginia.  The railroad went into receivership after trying to burrow through difficult terrain.  It was up to Colis Huntington, one of the “Big Four” in the transcontinental railroad, wanted to use the C&O as a railroad to link with his West Coast empire.  Additionally, West Virginia and surrounding states in Appalachia had a large reserve of natural resources which would form the revenue stream for the C&O for years to come.

Your object is to mimic (and beat) the C&O's success.

The game starts with the player taking a loan for money to pay for track and locomotives to haul goods.  Play consists of rolling dice for each commodity in the board.  Some commodities such as coal are more plentiful than manufactured goods.  After the commodities are placed, track is built, link by link, using the railroad's treasury.  Locomotives may be purchased which have a range of anywhere from 5-10 links.  After this is complete, if a player is able, he may transport cubes to any market expecting them.

There are also markets in the game which decide the price of a commodity based on how often it is delivered and how often cubes are placed on the board.  These values are staggered for different cities.

For those who have played a number of train games, this game could be described as a cross between Silverton and Age of Steam with a little bit of Prairie Railroads thrown in for good measure.  The main challenge of this title was to create a compelling solitaire railroading experience.  The game is extremely difficult to beat.  I think it lives up to the challenge.

Rush Hour Scramble is a multi player competitive version of the popular solitaire puzzle game. Each player designs a Rush Hour challenge for another player to solve. Players switch boards and race to be the first to solve their challenge. The player who solves his/her challenge first is the winner.

A copy of Rush Hour is needed for each player.

49 cards. There are six races (suits) - British, Turkish, Indian, Choctaw, Negro, Japanese. Each race has 8 ranked cards, starting with The Baby and ending with The King. The cards are also numbered from 1 to 8.
Each player gets 6 counters. Take out the Old Maid card as it is not used in the main game. Then the cards are dealt out to each player but an extra hand should also be dealt. This extra hand should remain face down and kept out of the game. Therefore, a few cards are not in play so will cause 'Stops' as the game proceeds.
The first player plays a card and announces its number and race. The next player must play the next card in rank for that race if he has it. If he doesn't then he says "I pass". There will probably come a point when the next highest card is not in play because all players will pass. In this case the player who played the last card, plays to the next round of play.
The Japanese Baby is a special card that allows the player to play it after he has just added a legal card, crying "Spin" as he does so. This means that the card he last played becomes a stop.
The game stops when one player has run out of cards. There are various rewards and forfeits and the player with the most counters wins.
Rules are included for the main game and two variants, Pool Spin and Old Maid (the publisher having added an Old Maid card for this version).

Use your head in this fun guessing game.

Pop a card into your opponent's headband and let them guess what they are.  Ask questions to guess your animal first.

This trivia game is an auto race across the continental U.S. by answering questions about the states. The game board poster, about 19" x 11", is a map of the U.S. with color coded paths for 4 roadsters. A correct answer advances your race car one point along the route.  An incorrect answer keeps the cars stationary until next turn.  The first race car to reach the end of the route (answering 10 state trivia questions correctly) wins the game.

You can develop the game further by creating your own flashcard questions about the states.

Includes 1 foldout game board, 4 game pieces, 48 state trivia cards.

Historic Gaming #7

Hero of Weehawken is a solitaire game in which the player takes the role of President Thomas Jefferson at a dangerous moment in the history of the United States. Former Vice President Aaron Burr is somewhere out west, and rumors abound that he is threatening the nation with plans for some sort of ill-advised military adventure that could bring America to war with Spain, or even a direct act of treason against the United States!

To forestall this disaster, you must first determine Burr’s real plans, then find and arrest him before he executes his plan; and, finally, gather sufficient evidence to convict Burr at trial. If your agents arrest him too soon, you will not have gathered enough evidence or figured out what to charge him with. If you wait too long, however, you may be too late to stop his nefarious plans.

Do you have what it takes to gather the right information in time? Be the judge and become the Hero of Weehawken!

Game Data:

Complexity: 2.5 on a 9 scale
Solitaire Suitability: 9 on a 9 scale
Scale: TBD

Game Components:

•    One 8-page full color Rules booklet with Examples of play
•    One 8.5” x 11” map
•    Two 8.5” x 5.5” mats (Plan and Trial)
•    One Player Aid sheet
•    32 5/8" square game pieces
•    60 Event cards

Trivia game linked to a very popular radio quiz hosted by Wilfred Pickles.

11 cards with 6 different questions on each one
1 Jackpot card
Rules

With so few questions provided, the replayability is very low.

Distribute the cards all round the room where the party is being held. Guests are encouraged to mingle and, whilst chatting, note down the answers to the 12 cartoon images. Each image depicts a character doing something - the guests have to work out what.

Party game.
The host places syllables all round the room. Players are instructed to find three syllables that make up the name of a British town; e.g. Ed-in-burgh. There are 33 towns listed on the host's Key Card, all made up of three syllables.
If you can make a town out of the syllables, you take it to the host who records you with 1 success and he will put the cards back in the box. Then the successful player goes back to the room to see if he can find another town.
After an agreed time, the player who found the most, wins.

Paper-and-pencil game where from 2 to 4 players aim to score as many points as possible by crossing existing lines of the opponent on an 8x8 board. Each player starts at one edge of the board (the starting field is the second to the right).

Each turn a player can draw in his colour a straight line crossing orthogonally one or two fields, or a bent line (one field crossed - corner on the next field - one field crossed). Spaces with corners or crossed both vertically and horizontally can't be crossed anymore. For each enemy line crossed a player scores one point. If one player's line can't be continued, they can start from another "free" square at their edge of the board. Play goes on until all players have used up their eight possible starting fields.

A Decktet memory game for two children.

From the Decktet wiki:

On your turn, declare "I am searching for ..." and name the suit from one of the unclaimed aces. Then move your token one card clockwise and turn over the card your token lands on, revealing it for everyone to see. If that card has the suit you were searching for, claim the ace of that suit - unless it was a Crown, which causes you to put back in the middle of the table the claimed ace of the Crown's suit if you have currently claimed it. The excuse does nothing when one of the face-down cards.

The younger player goes first, unless the game was just played and someone one, in which case the previous game's loser goes first. Players take turns until all six aces are claimed. The player who claims the most aces wins. If both players claim three aces the game is a draw.

This game teaches investors the difference between investments and corresponding risks.

Each player receives a sum of money and can invest in either shares, bonds, real estate, gold or..., depending on his movement on the board. The game controls the influence of the stock-market by event cards.

The game ends in a predefined time of when several rounds (years) are passed, the winner is the player with the best return of value

Three Royal Navy cruisers encounter the German pocket battleship Admiral Graf Spee off the eastern coast of South America, December 13, 1939.

"Battle of the River Plate" is a realistic tactical wargame of WW2 ship vs. ship naval combat for two players.  A Minden Games revised zip-lock edition of the Graf Spee wargame which appeared in Panzerschreck magazine #13.  Provides new ship ratings, and introduces new rules and modifications congruent with the Battleship Captain standard game system.

Battleship Captain is a "miniatures" game system with scenarios played on the tabletop or floor, using the rules and ship counters provided.  The game emphasizes playability, as players maneuver their ships and try and defeat the enemy fleet. Historical scenarios range in size from small (such as River Plate and Denmark Strait), which have only four or five ships to large (such as Tsushima and Jutland), which involve dozens of ships.

The game also requires tape measure or ruler in inches, paper and pencil, and a six-sided die.

--from the published game and the Minden Games web site

A Custom Monopoly Board Game for Laguna Beach, California.
The object of LagunaOpoly game is to become the wealthiest resident of Laguna Beach by buying, operating, and selling local businesses.  The game ends when all but one Enterpriser has gone broke. This remaining player is the WINNER of the game.

Contents:

     1 Game board
     28 Business ownership deeds
     16 Risk cards
     16 Laguna treasure cards
     16 Plastic hotels
     28 Plastic houses
     1 Set of money
     4 Bowling pin pawns
     2 Standard 6-sided dice

Coin Rail Yard is a Solitaire game (1 player) where the player will take on the duties of the yardmaster for the game's Rail Yard. The player will operate the Locomotives which will break-down arriving Trains and build-up departing Trains.
   The player will run through one of the sixteen scenarios, keeping track of how many turns that it took to complete the day's work. The final score will be determined by the number of turns plus any penalty occurred for mistakes. 
   There is a small amount of randomness in the game. There is also some flexibility in how the rail cars are arranged in the yard before the first Train arrives. This randomness and flexibility means that a scenario need not play out the same way the second time through. The game also comes with the guidelines for how to generate your own scenarios.
   Several expansion maps are planned.

A press-your-luck game of fraught cuisine for the Decktet.

Flip a card face up and then flip another. Continue until there are cards showing four or more of the six Decktet suits.

Active players simultaneously indicate whether they intend to take a bowl now or wait for more ingredients.

If the additional card makes it so that the face up cards include at least one instance of each of the six Decktet suits, then the soup has gone Turtle Butt. The soup night is over. Return any chips in the pot to the bank. Players who didn't take a bowl get nothing for that night.

The game should be played for at least five soup nights. Obviously, you can make the game longer by playing more nights. In the end, each small chip collected is worth 1 point and each large chip is worth 5. The player with the most points wins.

‘Demons run when a good man goes to war.’
This is an unauthorised, non-profit, print-and-play game inspired by the BBC TV show Doctor Who episode ‘A Good Man Goes to War’ (Series 6, Episode 7). The basic game mechanism is a kind of reverse werewolf/mafia game where the secret character, The Doctor, is the only person who can’t kill anyone and has to survive on wits and confusion alone.

Background: (Or buy the DVD and watch it!)
Human soldiers and the mysterious headless monks are working together in an uneasy alliance. They have kidnapped The Doctor’s companion (Amy Pond) and taken her to the asteroid know a Demon’s Run. The Doctor arrives on the asteroid disguised as one of the monks but reveals himself and demands Amy’s return. The lights go out and then back on, all orchestrated by the doctor, of course. Now the soldiers are stood there facing the monks. The soldiers know that one of the monks is their feared enemy, The Doctor, determined to foil their plans. All they have to do is to work out which monk is The Doctor in disguise and shoot him before he escapes. But if they shoot the wrong monk they will feel the wrath of their allies and be killed themselves by the monks dying blast. The monks themselves know that the soldiers are trigger happy and might shoot them. It might be best for them to zap any of the trigger happy soldiers before they themselves are killed - at least the other soldiers would know that they were a monk and not The Doctor. But the monks’ plan needs the soldiers and if they lose all of their soldiers then their plans will fail and The Doctor will triumph. The soldiers and monks need to act quickly before The Doctor is able to escape. The scene is set for the Demon’s Run Standoff.

The Game:
The players take on the role of soldiers, headless monks and The Doctor through a series of standoffs. During each standoff: the soldiers try to kill The Doctor; the monks try to direct the soldiers to The Doctor, and The Doctor just tries to survive. At the end of the standoff, points are given to players whose characters are still alive.

C. C. Higgins Rail Pass is a railroad board game that lets you relive the excitement of a railroad executive in the heyday of rail travel.

Basically a roll-and-move game without the dice, passes may be used to facilitate free rail travel. Collect color-coded sets of  rail passes as you travel the rails of North American railroad companies of 1920. Plan your routes as you race to designated payday cities utilizing the free travel from the rail passes you obtain along the way. The goal of the game is to garner the most points by combining rail passes into various sets defined by having the most passes in color categories and types of Railroads. C. C. Higgins Rail Pass is a completely luck-free strategy game that is both simple and extremely flexible in play.

Keel-Hauled! is a dice game for 2 to 4 players.  Although the game does contain some complexity, it is relatively simple to learn.  Play time for a full game of 50 points is usually less than an hour.

Players are pirates who vie for the position of Captain on a pirate ship.  To to this, players must roll their dice to assemble sets that first match the number on the "Crew Dice" which represent the Cabin Boy, Ship's Cook, and First Mate.  This becomes more challenging as there are limited spaces on the boat for dice sets to be placed, and the first player can change throughout the game.

The game is normally continued until one player scores 30 to 50 points, when the player with the most points overall is dubbed the new Captain of the ship.

Keel-Hauled has been discontinued, and is no longer available at The Game Crafter website.

Shuffle deck. Deal out to each player one card at a time until all cards are dealt out. Each player checks their cards and discards all pairs. The player to the left of dealer offers their hand to the player on their left hiding cards from their view. That player then takes one card from the hand. Again, any pairs are discarded. Playing continues. "The Boss" card can be passed around several times. The object is to be left with "The Boss" card. Finally, when all pairs are laid down, there will be one person left with "The Boss" card. That person is "Boss of ‘The Family’".

Pass safely through the traffic! Policeman Paul help players: There are many different picture cards to for close examination. Whoever assesses the traffic situation correctly will move ahead. Traffic lights, zebra crossings, footpaths and road game - this game teaches children how to behave in traffic and gain independence.

---

German Box Back
Sicher durch den Verkehr! Polizist Paul hilft spielerisch dabei: Viele verschiedene Bildkarten regen zum genauen Hinsehen an. Wer die Verkehrs-Situationen richtig einschätzt, kommt gut voran. Ampel, Zebrastreifen, Fußweg und Spielstraße - mit diesem Spiel lernen Kinder das richtige Verhalten im Verkehr und gewinnen an Selbstständigkeit

The batlle continues between the lonesome cowboy and the most notorious outlaws in the West. This game is a battle of wits, with Lucky Luke and his faithful steed Jolly Jumper on one side, and the Dalton brothers and Ma Dalton on the other.

The game consists of a plastic board, 8 squares by 8, on which are placed 64 counters. The orange counters represent Lucky Luke and  Jolly Jumper. The purple counters the Dalton brothers and Ma Dalton.

Rules: the game is for 2 players. The aim is to get 5 counters in a row (4 Lucky Luke + Jolly Jumper or 4 Daltons + Ma Dalton)
Each player puts down one counter at a time, and his opponent must try to stop him making a line, ath the same time gaining points himself. each complete line is worth 1 point, and the player with the highest number of points is the winner

Game Overview

In Atlantida you control a faction of the people of Atlantis that, after a series of catastrophes that turn their once glorious civilization to a semi-barbaric state, must move to the safety of the continent to avoid perish in the island inevitable collapse.
There are 13 turns, in which you must explore the island to gather resources, develop your city and discover technologies and advances in order to be able to send your population to safety. The winner is the first to save all her people or the most efficient to save them in the moment the island collapses.

Game Development

Even though the Atlantida already works as intended and the general idea is defined, it is still subject to changes. The game was developed directly for the yucata.de website, aiming to benefit from multiple plays which can provide a fair amount of players' feedback and suggestions. It is possible to play it "live", though, using the print and play files and rules at the Files section.

Online Play

     Yucata (turn-based)

Game where math skills, color blending, critical thinking and fast-paced, finger-flicking fun meet.

This intriguing game is a fun way for children to explore combinations and blends of colors. For example, by shifting the yellow and blue levers, they guide a marble into the green slot.  By shifting the red, yellow and white levers, they guide a marble into the peach slot. To win, all slots must be filled with two marbles of matching colors. It's a great test of visual tracking, mental aerobics and hand-eye coordination.

Contents:

     1 Plastic game board


(with 32 marbles, 2 plastic legs
and wind-up timer)

The object of Pool Party game is to be the first player to bring their frogs (disks) into a row, starting from the smaller inner circle next to the island and continuing in a straight line out to the largest circle is the winner.  Which frolicking frog will be first to hop in and form a row in the pool?  Only the dice can say.  This suspenseful game encourages kids to call on their thinking, basic math and social skills.

Contents:

     1 Game board
     30 Frogs (disks)


(Each disk size is in 6 colors: red, blue, green, purple, orange, yellow)
5 Large disks (1-3/16")
5 Semi-large disks (1-1/16")
5 Medium disks (7/8")
5 Semi-medium disks (13/16")
5 Small disks (19/32")

     2 Standard 6-sided dice

Unique charade card game where the players have to throw a dice and then depending of the number that comes up have the possibility to have drawn the same amount of pictures to figure out whats on the other players card.
The dice rolls... and it is a «2»! The player has the right to 2 drawings in order to make you guess by association of ideas, the object drawn on his card.

Contents:

     100 cards featuring 600 objects in all, 
     5 pads of paper, 
     5 pencils
     2 special dice.

A luminous observation game: The cards all look the same at first glance, so it's not so easy to pair them up.

Object of the game is create as many pairs as You can. Players mix the cards then place them on the table with the "5 geometric forms" side facing upwards. All the players play at the same time. Once the signal is given, each player looks at the cards and tries to find identical pairs. As soon as a player thinks he has created a pair, he takes two cards, places them in front of him and continues to search for other pairs. But watch out for mistakes as the cards are very similar!In fact, all the cards contain the 5 same geometric shapes; only their location differs from one card to the other. You are not allowed to touch the cards except to finally take them!

Game ends when there are no more cards in the centre of the table, or it does not seem possible to create another pair (if the players have taken incorrect pairs), each player checks the pairs that he has created. Winner is the player with the most correct pairs.

Components:

     48 luminous cards

Pirate Polo is a frantic live-action game for 2 - 4 "pirates". The game is played using a mini-trampoline as the playing surface. Each player has 5 dice of a single, unique color. In the center of the mini-trampoline is set a heavy, non-fragile cereal bowl. The players space themselves evenly around the mini-trampoline and place all five of their dice on the game surface in front of them. Each player has a polo mallet (at times also known as a serving spoon). On the starting signal, all players strike underneath the mini-trampoline with their polo mallet to try to propel their dice into the bowl. The first player to get all 5 dice in the bowl is the winner. This game is an alternative to the difficult to obtain Piratenbillard.

Academe is a quick, cooperative, filler card game for 3 players: one Thinker, one Teacher and one Builder.  The players must expend and earn Ideas, Knowledge and Material by building inventions.  Possible inventions are determined by turning over cards in rounds, and the player must choose which invention to build in each turn.  If, by the end of the three rounds of the game, the team has earned enough of these three commodities to build a University, they win the game.

Because it is non-competitive, it can also be easily played by fewer than 3 people, if one player wants to play more than one character.  In addition, the commodity targets can be lowered to make the game easy to win, for young children.

Players roll 2 dice and try to match the sum of the dice in his bingo sheet (numbers 2-12). Player who fills his sheet first is the winner

Contents:

     score pad, 
     2 dice, 
     cup

Game description from the publisher:

It is 1926, and the museum's extensive collection of exotic curios and occult artifacts poses a threat to the barriers between our world and the elder evils lurking between dimensions. Gates to the beyond begin to leak open, and terrifying creatures of increasing strength steal through them. Animals, the mad, and those of more susceptible minds are driven to desperation by the supernatural forces the portals unleash. Only a handful of investigators race against time to locate the eldritch symbols necessary to seal the portals forever. Only they can stop the Ancient One beyond from finding its way to Earth and reducing humanity to cinders.

Elder Sign is a fast-paced, cooperative dice game of supernatural intrigue for one to eight players by Richard Launius and Kevin Wilson, the designers of Arkham Horror. Players take the roles of investigators racing against time to stave off the imminent return of the Ancient One. Armed with tools, allies, and occult knowledge, investigators must put their sanity and stamina to the test as they adventure to locate Elder Signs, the eldritch symbols used to seal away the Ancient Ones and win the game.

To locate Elder Signs, investigators must successfully endure Adventures within the museum and its environs. A countdown mechanism makes an Ancient One appear if the investigators are not quick enough. The investigators must then battle the Ancient One. A clever and thematic dice mechanism pits their exploration against monsters and the sheer difficulty of staying sane and healthy, all within the standard game duration of one to two hours.

This football strategy game revolves around a pair of selector cups, one for each player. The cups are built into the thick gridiron board and function as dials that determine the play selected by each coach.

The outcome of each offensive play is determined by die rolls in the selector cups. The offensive team rolls for yardage gained. The defensive player rolls two dice that can generate random events like a fumble or a penalty.

Play follows the rules of football with punts, field goals, and every other element of the sport.

The board includes a sliding football marker and a matching first down marker that also slides up and down the field. There is a huge scoreboard plus the rulebook.

Published in 1978 by Wildcard, Inc.
An educational game based on an earlier British game.  One of the first games published in the USA.

This is game #6 in the Games on Half a Checkerboard Series.

F.I.L.O is a sowing game like those in the Mancala family.  Unlike games normally found in the Mancala family, F.I.L.O uses a first in, last out (FILO) mechanism for sowing pieces on the board, which is the basis of its name.  This mechanism, combined with the attributes of the 8x4 board, takes F.I.L.O in directions not normally seen with games in the Mancala family.

This is game #8 in the Games on Half a Checkerboard Series.

2-5 Skidoo a press-your-luck game for 2 players on an 8x4 board, in the family of games that includes games like Can't Stop, Cosmic Wimpout, 500, Farkle, Ten Thousand, and Pass the Pigs. The name is derived from the phrase “23 skidoo”.

In this game, each of the 4 columns on the 4x8 board correspond to numbers 2-5.  During a turn a player rolls 6 six-sided dice (numbered 1-6).  They pick three to add up, to beat a target number (this is either zero on their first roll, or what their last total was).  The players then take one of the remaining 3 dice and apply it to one of their columns.

If a player can't apply a die to advance one of their pieces, or don't beat their target number, all advancement resets.

Play continues until a player gets all four of their pieces off the board.

This is game #10 in the Games on Half a Checkerboard Series

This game is in the family of games that includes Amazons, and Slimetrail where the object is to cause one's opponent to not be able to move due to the number of spaces available on the board gets reduced as players play the game.  Each player has a piece that has a move like a Chess Knight and also put down barricades to restrict movement.  From these two elements comes the name of the game.

The goal of the game is to get ten clothing and fashion items, by answering questions related to the fashion and glamour world. When you annswer correctly, you get money, with which to buy the items you need. After several rounds, the final phase of the game consists in a final question. Depending on how good your item selection was, the answer will be easier or more difficult.

Really close to happy families or games of trades, the goal is to collect a complete set of cards.

the theme of the game is first aid and families are related to to it (hazardous Products, first aid kit, holiday hazards, ect..)

after asking for a card, you need to answer the question on the card to win it.

The first player to collect a complete set win the game.

Cave Girl takes the S&G combat system to prehistoric times. In this game, a cave girl named Sharr must compete for her existence with dinosaurs. each character in the game comes with several cards designating their fighting abilities which can be used in battle. There are several scenarios included with the game.

Each turn, players activate a character which can take up to two actions, including fight, move, rest, climb, or stand/go prone. Characters can attack enemies that are one square away for melee attack or may use ranged attack for enemies further away. Fighting is based on power of the weapon, power of the character's attack strength, and power of the enemies defense strike. The hit points are calculated via 2D6 - the power of the attack. For example, if an attack had a total strength of 6 and a 10 was rolled, the attack would have a power of 4. Victory is achieved by having a character remain on a certain part of the board for three complete uninterrupted turns.

NHL Breakaway is a new and exciting action packed 2 player strategy card game. You and your opponent draw from the deck of cards placed between you. When you go to draw cards from the pile, you will draw Player Cards (they represent the players on your team), Instant Replay Cards (intangibles which may momentarily affect a player or team’s performance) or Slapshot Cards (cards that have a more permanent effect on your team and the overall game).
With the help of your Player Cards and your other cards, try to win Possession of the puck during the face-off and then to go on the Attack to score more goals than your opponent over the course of 3 periods of play.

Your best friends are getting married, you are going to a family party, you are organising a friends weekend... And what if you spiced things up a bit by getting all these partygoers to kill each other?

The organiser gives everyone an assignment and a target amongst the attendees and gets ready to count the dead... As soon as a killer has accomplished his mission, he takes the assignment and the target of the dead person for himself.  At the end of the game, the best serial killer and the last man standing will be rewarded!

The goal of Killer Party is to be the one person to succeed in the hunt, but all the others are trying to stab you in the back...

String Railway: Transport is a follow-up game to String Railway, a train game in which the play area is created by placing varying lengths of colored string representing different types of terrain. The board is initially seeded with all the stations (unlike in String Railway) placed randomly inside the boundary string and filled with two goods cubes.

Each turn, players must place one string that connects stations. Then players have a number of action points to use. Players start with a 3 AP locomotive, and can upgrade to better locomotives that provide up to 6 AP per turn. Action points are used to moving goods cubes (1 AP to move from station to station). If a cube reaches a station of the same colour as the cube itself, the cube is then scored.

After five rounds, the cubes are scored. Each set of five cubes of different colours is worth 15 points, 4-cube sets are 10 points, 3-cube sets are 6 points, 2-cube sets are 3 points and remaining single cube sets give 1 point each. White wild cubes can be very useful at this point. Unfulfilled missions are -2 points, while perfectly fulfilled missions are +5 points.

String Railway: Transport, with a playing time of approx. 15 minutes per player, differs from the original game by adding cargo delivery and removing the values of stations. Transport is an individual game, not an expansion. The games are not compatible: you can't play String Railway with the components of Transport (the stations are different and there's no river).

Super GÅ‚owa is a Polish crossword game, not unlike Scrabble, in which words are formed on the board with the use of tiles; these words are awarded points with a special bonus system. The difficulty and intellectual level of this game depends on the players.

This game is targeted at both adults, who will find it an interesting way of spending their free time with their friends and families, and children, for whom it will be both a fun game and a learning opportunity. This game aids the development of intelligence, vocabulary and spelling skills.

Components:
- four wooden tile holders
- one thick cardboard board
- 126 cardboard square letter tiles (Polish characters included)
- 2 blank tiles

Flossie Carrington had it all - she was young and beautiful, she was the heiress to an American steel empire, and she was married to a handsome ex-Guards officer. But last Thursday, the nation was shocked by the discovery of her body, stuffed under the seat of a first-class compartment on the Plymouth Express. She had been stabbed to death and her fabulously expensive jewels were stolen.

Flossie's father promptly called in Hercule Poirot to investigate. And now he has summoned all those concerned with the case to reveal what really happened that fateful afternoon. One - or more - of you around this table is a murderer. And your task is to discover who that is.

This is the new edition of A First Class Murder, with a new plot and new characters, based on a couple of Agatha Christie's mysteries.

A set collecting game. Cards are traded noisily until one player has at least five of one team. The first to do so cries "Piktee" and scores 50 points and claims the Free Kick card, and a new deal starts (the Free Kick card has no purpose at all so I do not know why it was included in the game).
If a player dares, he may not call out his 5 card team but he can wait to get a six card team. If he is still the first to call "Piktee" he will score double points but, of course, by waiting, someone else might call a team before him and he will not score.
The Penalty card is exactly that, a penalty card. If you are caught with it in your hand when "Piktee" is called, you lose 25 points.
The first player to score 500 points after several deals, wins.

A feeding frenzy for two bunnies.

This is a simple fishing game of capturing cards off the tableau. The game starts with an 8x3 grid of cards face up on the table.  After splitting the undealt cards (using a split the pie mechanism) the players capture cards by playing one or more cards whose rank adds up equal or higher than the card being captured.  Each of the capturing cards must share a suit with the card being taken. After the tableau is cleared, the players add up the values of their captured cards to determine the winner.

Even though the game was designed as a light game, it is almost completely a perfect information game.  The only moment where there is not perfect information is when the players determine the split of the hand -- and even then they can figure out which cards the opponent is splitting.  As such it could be played as a very memory heavy, intense, spatial game.

The game was inspired by the designer's pet rabbit who is by far the most enthusiastic and fastest eating bunny the designer has ever seen. The girl has no problems yanking food right out of her partner's mouth, but is readily aggrieved if she does not get her fair share of the produce.

First in a series of Hex and Counter war games at Battalion level covering the Napoleonic Era.

Austerlitz is fought over a number of A3 boards (3 for Austerlitz). Counters represent the major units of Infantry,Cavalry, and Artillery units that fought the battle.

Movement is conducted at both Grand Tactical Level ( Some units may move more than others) and Tactical Level depending on the Battle fought. Here, movement is dealt at the Tactical Level only with four phases being Move,Fire,Melee,and Resolution.The Grand Tactical Level is merely the turn record of the battle which lasts 24 turns from 0600 hours to 1800 hours.

Battles are fought at both a Fire and Melee stage, Fire being those units firing which are in range of the enemy by using a dice + fire add on factors - Defensive attributes to achieve a final score. If the score is equal or greater the the units vulnerability score (7), units are placed face down and rendered non-operational.

In the melee stage, those units which did not fire in the Fire tactical stage may now battle and use one dice + Melee add on factor to achieve a final score. If the final score is greater than 6 against a non-operational unit, then that unit is destroyed.

Victory is decided by the player with the  most units left after 24 turns.
